header.rec_loc: A café in the town square, Tarnow, Poland
header.topics: Holiday plans, gym, cleaning, CV & job applications, teaching/learning a language, cats, housemates, friends, identity.
header.activity: Two friends talking about various topics (see 9 above) in a café in Tarnow, Poland.

speaker.occupation: unemployed/ Some part-time private TEFL teacher/ Semi-retired
Teacher of English as a foreign Language

body.u: while you were in the loo I was just reading this email
er m from my friend who I'm gonna go to erm Spain with in April

so we've looked at this place I sent him some accommodation links and he said oh I like this one and I said well I like that one too let's go for that then so a long story cut short or less short erm the woman wants a bank transfer she doesn't make it possible for you
and I feel a bit uncomfortable with that cos the website is full of these adverts saying
if you book through the website you get this protection and that protection blah blah blah so I'm not so happy about just sending money to a random bank account
she could've been hacked or whatever
and you have to pay for international transfer
exactly this is very true erm so I said this to and came up with some other suggestions of where to go and he's just realised his Irish passport's run out
or is running out and curious thing in Northern Ireland you can have either erm and post offices in Northern Ireland will give you a form for down south Ireland

and down south Ireland will give you a form for up north Ireland or UK erm so he said he was thinking the same about the prices and blah blah blah erm blah blah blah he said I went to the post office this is in the bottom of the peninsula arse end of nowhere to get an Irish passport renewal form they've run out of them at the moment but they said supplies them that's the local chip shop
erm but the local chip shop man who seems to be in his chip shop twenty-four seven is also the local councillor so
so yeah but it makes sense I suppose that as a
he's probably got all sorts of forms together with his
running a solicitors back through the back

outdoor like nook bit where you can
sit on the comfy cushions and read a book and look at the sea so
good good good glad you've got it you've got the ball rolling and
so how are you? what have you been up to?
yeah I'm really good I'm good
erm you know it's really funny if he really pushes it or I push myself and he sort of helps
when did you see him again?
yeah so that's why I'm sweating so much
cos I ran home had a shower ate s hot food walked here
with a coat on and it's really hot
it's really hot outside I know
erm so upper body really good erm I think sometimes it's surprising with how strong some parts of my body are
and then really surprised er with how weak the rest some bits are
so we were you know doing whatever and I was holding again this weight which weighs nothing half a bag of sugar and I was just like what?
that's enough oh so he was like right do ten with this er h tiny tiny weight and then do ten with just moving your arms
it's just like I'm so weak my exercise is just moving my arms up and down
oh my god have you ever been to a craniologist?
it's erm like a bizarre branch of osteopathy or erm chiropractic or whatever
erm and they play about with bits in your head
and I used to see this guy I think he was a chiropractor primarily erm but he would do these sort of strength test things
by getting you to hold up an arm or push here or pull there or whatever and based on that and where he detected weaknesses
he would then prod bits on my head and like really push into bits on your skull
and then he'd like leave me to set for five minutes and then he'd come back and do the strength test again and it was so different
yeah it's nuts I'm not sure of the science behind it but he obviously linked it in with chiropractic
yeah no it's just you know I really worked on you know if er if you notice like really quick improvements you tend to do that more than where the res the improvements are slow
so those bits naturally become the weakest over time
so whereas I can fling around eighteen kilos with one arm like it's nothing
I can't hold a two kilogram plate in front of me with
without like dropping it or falling over
I'll get there it'll get there
well I'm pleased you can walk again that was a little bit of a concern these last few days so
I know cos I was when we got back I was just sort of googling it and if you tear or pull a muscle there's three stages

and the first one is it hurts but you don't have any sort of noticeable limp er you know you can still walk the second one which is what I think I had but quite severely is noticeable limp hurts to do anything twinges
and a slow pain it hurts even when you're sitting or lying
and then the third one is like completely fucked can't do anything at all ever
and you hear when it happens you hear like a pop
of like the muscle like coming into pieces
I didn't have that one erm and it said
but you just had a bad number two?
and it said sort of er a week two weeks until back to normal erm
you've been less than a week

I don't want it to go bad
and with the calves I just said only bodyweight
I know that's pretty crazy to start with really
and they're difficult muscles to warm up as well cos
really you're sort of warming them up with your bodyweight cos that's
the minimum you can do and
so we'll just have to take it slowly
he said do you want to skip it all together? I said no
because that's stupid we'll just have to do it really sort of sensibly
er cos you know the my legs can hack a hell of a lot like they can take a lot of weight

it's cos your skin's drier in winter anyway I suppose

and I can relate to everybody blah blah blah

and you know so I'm really and then I was like right no do it on two pages and I was like oh but it looks so nice on one
and you know if I if I was looking at CVs and it had everything on one page I'd be like well they're obviously and organised boom
erm whereas I've seen CVs of like three and four pages and you're like
are you still harping on about Duke of Edinburgh you did when you're fifteen and you're now twenty-seven?
move on move on but I'm putting it into two pages with quite hefty erm bits for each school including you know the textbooks that I used
mm yep and I think the CV's an entirely different document for whatever job you're applying for
so no two CVs of yours
yeah I did recruitment for in various job roles for donkey's years and I didn't take CVs
and if people didn't read the big thick bold print that said people who send CVs will have their applications ignored then
you know more fool them so I used to ignore those and that stopped a lot of on-spec applications
and people just firing them off which frankly pissed me off I wanted to know that people want not just a job but my job
and they wanna work for my organisation as part of my team
mm what? so was it er like a a form with questions?

yeah so it was a form with questions saying you know not even some quite often with jobs you'll get the job description person specification and then it'll say look at that and then fill in the boxes to say how it applies erm but no I mine were more specific in saying for this role you need this this and this skill tell us about a time when you have used these skills
give examples erm so it's much more specific and it was the sort of application that if you did it properly would take a long time to fill in
but hopefully you then get the right people I mean y
and you do get people who are shit at filling in forms but brilliant at doing the job
and you can spot them a bit
if they've had you know six years at this place which is similar
and ten years at that place which is similar whatever so yeah it was interesting interesting times
had very high staff turnover one charitable organisation that I worked for in the first two years I pretty much overhauled half the team
and got new people in who were magnificent made a big difference to the effective running of everything it was wonderful erm but because of that and I had so much shor
did you fire them? or force them out? or make them redundant?
erm people had the choice to get up to the standard or to go away
and people that wanted to get up to the standard I was very supportive
and erm also sending them to other shops and sort of buddying them up with other managers
who they could take to and would support them as well erm some people couldn't be arsed

didn't really like the job they were doing anyway and probably better off out of it quite frankly and then and so I brought in very passionate people who loved what they were doing loved the team and brought that energy to the table which was wonderful but anyway yeah so I used to do a lot of shortlisting usually with a bottle of wine of an evening erm but you do get a feel for it and that passion comes through
yeah but no if you see these yeah I suppose you have a basic template but then tweak it to the job you're applying for
mm I don't think it it matters so much though in this industry a job in a school is the s the same

between jobs between schools that you're applying for

compare with your partner see if you're sort of similar people

it was just like any way to get them to talk about it

and you can build it up over time as well to build up you know it's like a vocab build-up over time
it's brilliant absolutely brilliant and I said to him at the end of the lesson you know I expected you to be a little bit slower or to have difficulty finding the words
